The category of people who can get tested is broader than only people with symptoms but it is NOT the case that tests are generally available.  Therefore H2=2 still seems most appropriate.    A recent press article describes the conditions that must be fulfilled to be eligible for a test as follows: "At the moment, not just anyone can get tested. Only people with a code from a contact locator or who have been referred by a GP can do this ... A test will not be refunded if a patient is not covered by Sciensano's procedural guidelines, but in principle the doctor should not perform that test."  (http://web.archive.org/web/20200731141101/https://www.standaard.be/cnt/dmf20200731_94091288)    The "Sciensano procedural guidelines" define the conditions for a test in more detail:  -"possible cases" based on symptoms  -or "confirmed cases"  -or people who had "high-risk contacts" or returned from an orange or red area    In case there is sufficient capacity:  -patients before starting hospital stay  -new inhabitants of retirement homes    (http://web.archive.org/web/20200731141715/https://covid-19.sciensano.be/sites/default/files/Covid19/COVID-19_Case%20definition_Testing_NL.pdf)    Some cities (like Antwerp) are building more generally available local test-capacity that will come online around 3 August.  But as this is for local residents only, H2=2 seems most appropriate.
